It is of great significance to study green and efficient sustainable energy catalysts for environmental and energy protection. Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are important electrocatalytic reactions. Here, through density functional theory calculations, we have designed ZnNC-Gra catalyst. All ZnNC-Gra have been proven to have satisfactory thermodynamic stability. The intermediate adsorbs on the substrate with obvious charge transfer. The higher the N concentration, the more electrons Zn loses. Combined with the calculation of Gibbs free energy, our results reveal that ZnN2C1-Gra has satisfactory stability and activity for OER, with an overpotential of 0.61 V. In addition, ZnN3C1-Gra exhibits ideal ORR activity with an overpotential of 0.45 V. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Single atom catalyst Oxygen redox Alkaline medium Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Faced with increasingly severe environmental and energy issues, electrochemical energy, as a green and clean energy source, can effectively replace traditional fossil fuels. Clean energy devices such as fuel cells can effectively convert chemical and electrical energy, and have high efficiency [1–4]. Compared with traditional fuel combustion, it has higher theoretical energy conversion efficiency. Oxygen redox is widely used in the field of electrocatalysis. Oxygen redox includes two electrocatalytic core reactions, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [5,6]. OER exist in discharge reaction of metal-air cells and water decomposition [7–10]. ORR mainly occurs in metal-air batteries, discharge reaction of metal-air cells and fuel cells [11]. However, the kinetics of these two reactions are slow, so efficient catalysts are needed to promote their reactions. At present, we are using expensive and poorly durable precious metal catalysts, such as Pt based catalysts and precious metal oxides (IrO2 and RuO2) [12–14]. Therefore, in order to achieve high conversion of electrical and chemical energy and replace precious metal catalysts, there is an urgent need to synthesize oxygen redox electrocatalysts with high-performance and selectivity [15–17]. The main four electron pathway product of ORR is water. And the product of the two-electron step reaction of ORR is hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). H2O2 is a widely used green oxidant. H2O2 is commonly used in medicine to clean wounds and prevent local bacteria. It is also widely used in bleaching, disinfection, water treatment, paper oxidation, chemical synthesis, and textiles [18]. The anthraquinone method is now the main industrial method for producing H2O2. However, the steps of anthraquinone oxidation/reduction technology are complex, including hydrogenation, oxidation, extraction, and purification. The production process consumes a lot of energy and generates a large amount of chemical waste, causing environmental and safety issues [19,20]. The above drawbacks make this technology neither energy-saving nor environmentally friendly, deviating from the original intention of green and renewable energy. Fortunately, the method of electrochemical reduction of O2 to H2O2 through 2e− transfer using ORR is safe and environmentally friendly. However, the high overpotential (ƞ) of ORR, as well as the expensive price and toxicity of precious metal catalysts, hinder the further development of this method. Therefore, finding electrocatalysts with high reactivity and selectivity is of great significance for the electrosynthesis of H2O2. Single atom catalyst (SAC) have a high volume to surface ratio, high metal utilization efficiency, and significant reaction selectivity, making SAC exhibit higher catalytic activity than bulk catalysts [21–25]. However, due to the continuous increase in high surface free energy, the separated atoms are easily aggregated into useless nanoparticles after high-temperature reactions, thereby weakening the catalytic activity [26]. Therefore, it is particularly important to find a suitable carrier to stabilize individual metal atoms while maintaining the excellent catalytic activity of SAC. Two dimensional (2D) materials are considered good support materials for anchoring individual metal atoms [27–29]. Among them, graphene is frequently employed in the field of electrocatalytic chemistry as an outstanding representative of 2D materials [30]. It can tolerate harsh circumstances such as strong acids and bases and has ideal electrical and geometric structures in addition to having great physical and chemical stability. Graphene in the form of flakes also has good thermal conductivity, conductivity, and high carrier mobility. As a consequence of its specific surface area, the structure and surface properties of graphene are adjustable. The benefits listed above demonstrate that graphene is an exceptional material used in electrocatalysis. In recent years, graphene supported SACs have received extensive research [31–34]. Many experimental studies and theoretical calculations have proven that N-doped graphene catalytic materials are a widely applied catalyst [35–40]. The TM-N-C structure is obtained by forming a coordination mechanism of carbon and nitrogen coexisting around transition metal atoms (TM) anchored in graphene [41–45]. TM is located at the center of N-doped graphene, increasing the coverage of active sites and metal utilization, effectively improving atomic stability and catalytic activity of the catalyst [46]. N and TM display special structural, electronic, and bonding interactions with further doping. The stability of the catalyst matrix is guaranteed by the distinctive covalent chemical connections between the C and N doping and the TM. In addition to enhancing reaction kinetics, loading TM onto graphene vacancies increases stability [47,48]. Compared to the expensive Pt TM, Zn is an affordable TM. And Zn, as an element of the same main group as Cd, has the same low boiling point property. The Cd-N-C catalyst has been studied by us [49]. The traditional ZIF-67 and ZIF-8 methods commonly used in experiments cannot prepare metal atom catalysts with low boiling points, as low boiling metal atoms will vaporize. But now, the preparation of Cd-N-C catalysts under non-high-temperature conditions has been discovered [50]. Zn-N-C catalysts can also be prepared in a similar way. In view of this, this paper presented a graphene structure doped with various N concentrations and anchored to a non-precious transition metal Zn. By means of density functional theory (DFT), the effects of the ZnNC-Gra electrocatalyst on ORR and OER were estimated systematically. Firstly, by calculating the binding energy and dissolution potential of the catalyst, and using kinetic simulation analysis, the stability of the catalyst was verified. Secondly, in order to demonstrate the performance of the catalyst substrate, the adsorption of various reactants, products, and intermediates were discussed, and the optimal catalytic configuration was obtained. Further analysis of charge distribution and electronic band structure revealed the relationship between the source of excellent catalysis and different configurations and N concentrations. To screen out high-performance catalysts, Gibbs free energy (∆G) and overpotential (ƞ) were calculated. Then the most favorable catalytic reaction path and the optimal catalyst ƞ were obtained. Finally, potential ORR and OER efficient catalyst configurations were proposed. 2 Computational details 2.1 Methods This article are based on Dmol3 code, using spin unrestricted DFT [51]. The electron exchange and other related effects are described using the Burke, Perdew, and Ernzerhof functional [52]. We used the DFT semi-core pseudopotentials method to perform a certain extent of relative correction on the metal atom Zn. To accelerate convergence, we used 0.002 Ha smearing. The selected base file was 4.4 DNP Basis. We used the aqueous solvents with a dielectric constant of 78.54. We used the Mulliken charge and Grimm's method to analyze the charge transfer and dispersion correction of the catalyst, respectively. The maximum difference of energy, displacement, and force in geometric optimization were 1 × 10−5 Ha, 0.005 Å and 0.002 Ha Å−1, respectively [53]. The Brillouin zone k-point and the Monkhorst-Pack k-point were chosen as 5 × 5 × 1 for better structural optimization and to ensure the accuracy of calculation results. Molecular dynamics (MD) was analyzed using 5.0 fs time steps and NVT method at 298.15 K. 2.2 Models and computational contents Here we construct single vacancy and double vacancy 5 × 5 × 1 periodic graphene layer, respectively. They have a vacuum layer with a thickness of 30 Å. As shown in Fig. 1 (a), by replacing one C on the graphene with an introduced Zn atom and substituting 1–3 C atoms surrounding the metal Zn with an equivalent number of strongly electronegative N atoms, the single vacancy configuration is created. There are four configurations in total. When N atom substitution is not introduced, the resulting structure is ZnN0C3-Gra system. The ZnN1C2-Gra system is generated when only one of the C atoms is substituted with one N atom. The ZnN2C1-Gra system is composed of two N atoms replacing C atoms. The ZnN3C0-Gra system is formed by replacing the three C atoms around Zn with three N atoms. And in Fig. 1(b), in the case of double vacancies, there are seven configurations. They are ZnN0C4-Gra system, ZnN1C3-Gra system, ZnN2C2-o-Gra system, ZnN2C2-p-Gra system, ZnN2C2-h-Gra system, ZnN3C1-Gra system and ZnN4C0-Gra system. Binding energy ( E b ) and dissolution potential ( U diss ) can be used to determine stability. The E b values of single and double vacancies in ZnNC-Gra systems can be calculated by Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. And the U diss value is calculated by Eq. (3) as follows [54–56]: (1) E b − SV = E SG − Zn − E SG − E Zn (2) E b − DV = E DG − Zn − E DG − E Zn (3) U diss = U Zn 0 − E b / Ne Among them, E SG and E DG represent the energy of graphene with one and two C atoms removed, respectively. Where E SG − Zn and E DG − Zn represent the energy of single vacancy graphene anchoring a metal Zn atom and double vacancy graphene anchoring a Zn, respectively. E C equals the energy of each carbon atom in the graphene superlattice. E Zn is the energy of a metal Zn atom, where the atom is an isolated atom. E b is the binding energy of metal atoms to the surface of the substrate. Including E b − SV and E b − DV respectively represent the metal binding energies of vacancies and divacancies. U diss represents the ability of metal elements to dissolve in an electrolyte. U Zn 0 is the standard dissolution potential of Zn in the bulk form, and the value is −0.76. Ne is the number of electrons involved in the dissolution for the pure metals, and the Ne of Zn is 2 [57,58]. Adsorption energy (∆E ads) and adsorption free energy (∆G ads) can display the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for reactants, products, and intermediates [59]. Through the calculation of the variation of ∆G, the rate determination steps of the reaction can be compared and further calculations can be made for the catalyst ƞ. The specific details of these calculation formulas are displayed in the supporting information. In alkaline medium, ORR has two electron transfer pathways: four electron and two-electron. Two-electron transfer generates the product H2O2, as shown in Eq. (4). The four-electron process can be further divided into two scenarios, as shown in Eqs. (5) and (6). (4) O 2 + * + H 2 O + e − → step 1 OO H * + H 2 O + O H − + e − → step 2 H 2 O 2 + * + 2 O H − (5) O 2 + * + H 2 O + e − → step 1 OO H * + O H − + e − → step 2 O * + H 2 O + O H − + e − → step 3 O H * + O H − + e − → step 4 * + O H − (6) O 2 + * + H 2 O + e − → step 1 OO H * + H 2 O + O H − + e − → step 2 2 O H * + O H − + e − → step 3 O H * + O H − + e − → step 4 * + O H − where * represents the catalysator. O*, OH* and OOH* respectively represents adsorption on the substrate are the oxygen-containing intermediates involved in the reaction process. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Stability of ZnNC-Gra Testing stability is an essential and important step for catalysts. During the reaction that occurs in environmentally friendly energy installation like fuel cells, transition metal catalysts will dissolve and redeposit, and then easily aggregate to form clusters. To demonstrate the stability of the catalyst, we simultaneously calculated E b and U diss. The calculated U diss values are all greater than zero, and the positive U diss indicates that the doped active atoms are not easily separated from the anchoring point and dissolve in the electrolyte. The E coh of Zn atoms is −1.35 eV. When the E b value of Zn is less than its E coh, it indicates that the transition metal Zn of the catalyst are relatively difficult to aggregate and form clusters, thus proving the stability of the catalyst. The obtained E b and U diss are shown in Table S1, respectively. It can be found that only the E b value of ZnN1C2-Gra is greater than the E coh. So, the metal Zn atom in the ZnN1C2-Gra catalyst is prone to diffusion and aggregation to form clusters, making the catalyst less stable. The E b values calculated for the other ten catalyst substrates are all greater than the E coh values. It is expected that Zn can have good stability on these catalyst substrates, reducing the possibility of metal atoms aggregating into large clusters. To further demonstrate the stability of the catalyst, we analyzed the dynamic of all catalyst structures discussed in this article. The simulation of dynamic analysis in NVT at 300 K is shown in Table S2. We can see that all structures remain flat after dynamic analysis, without significant distortion. After every picosecond of reaction, the structural oscillation is very small, and the structure has high stability. This indicates that the structure of these catalysts is stable and can be further explored theoretically. The Mulliken charge distribution in the central part of the 11 catalytic substrates shown in Fig. 2 . The transition from red to blue represents the conversion of atoms from electron loss to electron gain. It can be clearly seen that except for the metal Zn atom in the ZnN0C3 structure, which obtained a small number of electrons, Zn in all other structures have lost electrons. In the catalyst structure doped with N, N obtains more electrons than C. We also calculated the distribution of Barder charges on ZnN2C1 and ZnN3C1 structures, as shown in Fig. S1. The blue and red values represent the accumulation and loss of electrons, respectively. Consistent with Mulliken's analysis, Zn atoms lose the most electrons in the entire substrate as active sites for the reaction, while N loses more electrons compared to C. The reason for this phenomenon is the presence of N atoms. The electronegativity of N and C is 3.04 and 2.55, respectively. N has a stronger ability to acquire electrons due to its greater electronegativity than C. Most of the gain and loss of electrons occur at the active center of the catalyst. In the case of a single vacancy, the higher the N concentration, the more electrons Zn loses (Zn0N < Zn1N < Zn2N < Zn3N). In the case of double vacancies, this pattern also exists (Zn0N < Zn1N < Zn2N < Zn3N < Zn4N). As is well known, catalysts used in electrocatalytic new energy devices such as fuel cells have excellent conductivity is indispensable. This article studied the conductivity of all catalyst substrates. The band gap of ZnN0C3-Gra, ZnN1C2-Gra, ZnN2C1-Gra, ZnN3C0-Gra, ZnN0C4-Gra, ZnN2C2-o-Gra, ZnN2C2-h-Gra, ZnN2C2-p-Gra and ZnN4C0-Gra are 0.057, 1.461, 1.445, 1.606, 0.650, 0.866, 0.736, 0.597 and 0.944 eV, respectively. ZnN1C3-Gra and ZnN3C1-Gra are conductors, and the rest are semiconductors. 3.2 Adsorption performance and catalytic activity The Zn on ZnNC-Gra serves as the active site for the reaction, and the reactants, intermediates, and products in the ORR and OER processes are adsorbed on it. O2 is an important reactant of ORR and an important product of OER. Significant research has been conducted on the adsorption of oxygen, mainly designing two types of oxygen adsorption configurations, namely (a) end on and (b) side on, as shown in Fig. S2. After structural optimization, all configurations are side on, which indicates that the energy is lower and more stable than end on model in this configuration. Wang and Liang et al. have demonstrated that the adsorption state of oxygen is the most stable under the side on structure, consistent with the conclusions obtained in this paper [45,59]. ∆ E ads of O2*, OOH*, O* and OH*, H2O* in ZnNC-Gra are shown in Table S3. There is a clear regular pattern in the ΔE of catalysts for oxygen-containing small molecules. Considering the ΔE of the same catalyst for O2*, OOH* and O*, the values of ΔE in descending order are ΔE O2, ΔE OOH, and ΔE OH. O2, as a complete gas molecule, has the smallest number of electron transfers with the substrate compared to O, OH, or OOH ions, so the substrate has the weakest adsorption capacity for O2. The ΔE OH and ΔE O in this article are similar in magnitude. And in ZnN2C2-h-Gra, ZnN2C2-p-Gra and ZnN3C1-Gra, the value of ΔE O is smaller than other structures, the adsorption strength of O is greater. The optimal adsorption configurations of O2*, OOH*, O*, OH*, 2OH*/H2O2* and H2O* on ZnNC-Gra electrocatalysts are shown in Table S4. In ZnN2C2-h-Gra, ZnN2C2-p-Gra and ZnN3C1-Gra, synergistic adsorption of O atom on metal Zn and a surrounding C atom, resulting in an increase in its adsorption energy. By comparing the ΔE of 2OH* and H2O2*, the value of H2O2* is closer to a positive value than 2OH*. That is to say, the adsorption energy of the catalyst for H2O2 is weaker than that of 2OH, making the generated H2O2 more easily desorbed from the substrate. ΔG ads of reactive species in ZnNC-Gra is shown in Table S5. It can be clearly seen that the ΔG OOH, ΔG O, and ΔG OH of single vacancy catalyst are arranged in descending order. As shown in Fig. 3 , the value of ΔE O2 decreases as the N concentration increases in the double vacancy configuration. In other words, an increase in the content of N doping helps to improve the substrate's ability to adsorb O2. Fig. 4 shows the partial differences of states (PDOS) for different types of ZnNC-Gra. It shows the hybridization phenomenon of 3d orbitals of Zn and O2's 2p orbitals in different ZnNC-Gra configurations. Further elucidating the catalytic adsorption reaction between O2 and substrate. As shown in Table S6, the d-band center of Zn and the p-band center of O2 are shown. We found that the d-band center of Zn in ZnN3C1-Gra is the closest to the Fermi level among the 11 catalysts, indicating that the closer the d-band center of Zn is to the Fermi level, the more favorable its catalytic activity is. The molecular orbital energy level diagram of O2 is shown in the Fig. S3. The highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of individual O2 molecules were calculated, with energies of −6.986 eV and −4.704 eV, respectively. And their energy gap is 2.282 eV. We found that the p-band center of Zn in ZnNC-Gra were all closed to the LUMO, as shown in Table S7. So the Zn atom in the substrate provides electrons to O2 molecule. This is consistent with the phenomenon of O2 showing negative charge in the catalyst configuration for adsorbing O2. In a single vacancy structure, as the N content increases, the value of the p-band center decreases. O* is an important catalytic intermediate configuration. Fig. 5 shows the deformation charge density map of O* in ZnNC-Gra. Here, ±0.07 electrons/Å3 isovalue is used. Blue and yellow represent the gain and loss of electrons, respectively. We can see that O is surrounded by light blue, while Zn is yellow, and there is a strong electron transfer phenomenon between Zn and O. Zn serves as the active center atom of the catalytic substrate, and the O atom of oxygen-containing intermediates mainly reacts with Zn atoms. The slightly protruding Zn atoms act as active centers and bond with the oxygen atoms of oxygen-containing intermediates. The most stable state of OOH* is also the side on structure. The length relationship of ZnO bonds of OH* and OOH* in ZnNC-Gra was studied, as shown in Table S8. We can see that the ZnO bond length of diverse catalysts in OOH is longer than the ZnO bond length in OH. Since the O at the end of OOH obtains electrons from both Zn and adjacent O. Under the influence of another O, the O atom at the end is further away from Zn. In the same vacancy structure, ZnO bonds exhibit similar bond lengths when adsorbing the same intermediate. 3.3 Catalytic performance of ORR and OER in ZnNC-Gra This article considers two types of oxygen reduction reactions, 2-electron, and 4-electron. The main reaction of ORR is the 4-electron step, and the side reaction is the 2-electron step. The product of the 4-electron step is H2O. The second electron product is H2O2. The 4-electron ORR reaction in alkaline medium is primarily separate into four parts. Firstly, O2 adsorbs on the catalytic substrate and forms bonds with the transition metal Zn. Reacting with H2O to lose an electron, forming OOH adsorbed on the substrate and producing an OH−. In the second step, continuing to lose one electron forms O* and generates another OH−. However, in the second step of the reaction, there is another situation where electrons are lost, that is, OOH* loses one electron in the reaction with H2O, resulting in the formation of 2OH* and OH−. The third step of the reaction continues to lose one electron, resulting in OH* and OH−. The final step of ORR is to lose one electron and eventually return to the form of the substrate and OH−. The difference between generating H2O2 and the four-electron step is that when it loses electrons in the second step, OOH* reacts with H2O to generate H2O2 and separate it from the substrate. OER and ORR are reciprocal reactions. The OER reaction process is completely opposite to ORR. Free energy diagrams of ORR/OER on ZnNC-Gra is demonstrated in Fig. 6 , (a) is the double vacancy configuration and (b) is the single vacancy configuration of ZnNC-Gra. As an exothermic reaction, the rate limiting step of ORR is the step with the least exothermic reaction. And OER is an endothermic reaction, so its speed limiting step is the one with the most endothermic reactions. As shown in Fig. 6, from left to right is the ORR reaction, and from right to left is the OER reaction. And the free energy diagram for the ORR and OER on ZnNC-Gra at equilibrium potential (U = 0.402 V) in alkaline medium is shown in Fig. S4. The specific η and ΔG of ORR in ZnNC-Gra are shown in Table S9 and the η and ΔG of OER are shown in Table S10. Among the four configurations with single vacancies, the reaction tends towards a four-electron step. Two electron side reactions are not easily generated. For ORR, the ƞ results corresponding to different reaction pathways are consistent. However, when the intermediate of the OER reaction is 2OH*, it can effectively promote the progress of the reaction. The ƞ of ZnN2C1-Gra is only 0.61 V. All single vacancy catalysts, OOH* is more inclined to generate 2OH*, but in the double vacancy, there are only two configurations: ZnN2C2-o-Gra and ZnN4C0-Gra. OOH* is easier to become O* in ZnN3C1-Gra. However, the 2OH* of ZnN0C4-Gra, ZnN1C3-Gra, ZnN2C2-h-Gra and ZnN2C2-p-Gra catalysts tends to generate H2O2* after structural optimization. Only the OOH * in ZnN0C4 Gra is more prone to react to generate H2O2*, while the rest are more prone to generate O*. However, the ORR rate limiting step of ZnN0C4-Gra is the first step (O2* to OOH*), with the ƞ of 1.03 V. Among the seven configurations of double vacancies. At ZnN2C2-o-Gra, the step from O2* to OOH* releases the lowest energy, which has ƞ ORR of 0.90 V and ΔG of 0.50 eV as well. For ZnN3C1-Gra, the step from O2* to OOH*, featuring ΔG of 0.02 eV and ƞ ORR of 0.45 V, is the reaction speed limit step respectively. At the ZnN4C0-Gra, the energy transition from OH * to H2O * (ΔG = 0.28 eV, ƞ ORR = 0.68 V) is the lowest. The highest energy absorption from O2* to OOH* occurs with ZnN1C3-Gra (ΔG = 0.31 eV, ƞ ORR = 0.71 V). Additionally, for ZnN2C2-h-Gra, the energy has its highest between O2* and OH*, with G = 1.34 eV and ORR = 1.74 V. And the transition between O2* and OH* at ZnN2C2-p-Gra, where ΔG is 1.37 eV, and ƞ ORR is 1.77 V, is also the step that absorbs the maximum energy. Vinogradov et al. constructed carbon catalysts doped with Co, Fe, Cu, and Ni, and obtained the ƞ ORR values are 0.52, 0.54, 0.72 and 1.02 V, respectively [38]. Zhang et al. calculated that the ORR of CoN2-O-gra, CoN2-F-gra, CoN2-F-gra, CoN1-S-gra and CoN3-gra were 0.94, 1.10, 0.98, 0.61 and 0.63 V, respectively and for OER were 1.68, 1.81, 1.69, 1.36 and 1.33 V, respectively [60]. Compared with the eleven electrocatalyst in this article, it can be concluded that ZnN3C1-Gra has the greatest catalytic capability of ORR, while ZnN2C1-Gra is an excellent catalyst for OER. 4 Conclusions In this contribution, the catalyst configurations of four single vacancy and seven double vacancy ZnNC-Gra configuration catalysts were analyzed. By using energy calculations and analysis of dynamics, it was found that the eleven catalysts studied in this article had excellent stability. Analyzing the Mulliken charge analysis of these catalysts, we concluded that the concentration of N doping can effectively change the amount of electron gain or loss. N atoms can acquire more electrons. The electron loss of the central atom Zn increased as the N content increased (Zn0N < Zn1N < Zn2N < Zn3N < Zn4N). We obtained the most stable adsorption configuration of reactants, products, and intermediates during the reaction process after structural optimization. Analyzing the adsorption of different substances, we found that Zn serves as the central site for reaction catalysis, and O is more likely to bond with metal Zn. The ZnO bond length between Zn-OOH* is longer than that between Zn-OH*. The charge distribution and transfer of O2* was discussed by using PDOS. By using the deformed charge density map, it can be clearly seen that the O atom in O* obtained electrons. So, the intermediate can effectively adsorb on the substrate and generate significant charge transfer. By ∆G and ƞ calculation and analysis, we got that ƞ ORR = 0.45 V at ZnN3C1-Gra, and ƞ OER = 0.61 V at ZnN2C1-Gra. To sum up, ZnN2C1-Gra has a good overpotential and is expected to be applied in the field of electrocatalysis. ZnN3C1-Gra can serve as an effective ORR catalyst. These findings can provide precise and detailed perspectives for future research and design of efficient ORR and OER electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: It is of great significance to study green and efficient sustainable energy catalysts for environmental and energy protection. Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are important electrocatalytic reactions. Here, through density functional theory calculations, we have designed ZnNC-Gra catalyst. All ZnNC-Gra have been proven to have satisfactory thermodynamic stability. The intermediate adsorbs on the substrate with obvious charge transfer. The higher the N concentration, the more electrons Zn loses. Combined with the calculation of Gibbs free energy, our results reveal that ZnN2C1-Gra has satisfactory stability and activity for OER, with an overpotential of 0.61 V. In addition, ZnN3C1-Gra exhibits ideal ORR activity with an overpotential of 0.45 V.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical analysis of single Zn atoms with N/C on graphene promoting oxygen redox in alkaline medium
